title: Ticket #6735: Delay between execution of jobs on Windows with shared_port enabled
description:
On Windows, when using the default configuration of 

   USE_SHARED_PORT = True

there appears to be a significant delay between the execution successive of jobs on the same claim/slot. This can add a lot of overhead if the jobs are short-running.

The problem appears to happen because the condor_starter takes a long time to exit after the job completes because the SIGTERM from the condor_startd to the condor_starter is not delivered. Behold the following clue from the StartLog: 

   08/10/18 13:38:36 Send_Signal: Warning: could not send signal 15 (SIGTERM) to pid 6488 (still alive)
   08/10/18 13:38:36 slot3: Error sending signal to starter, errno = 42 (Illegal byte sequence)
   08/10/18 13:38:36 slot3: State change: Error sending signals to starter
   08/10/18 13:38:36 slot3: Changing state and activity: Preempting/Vacating -> Owner/Idle
   08/10/18 13:38:36 slot3: State change: IS_OWNER is false
   08/10/18 13:38:36 slot3: Changing state: Owner -> Unclaimed
   08/10/18 13:38:36 Starter pid 6488 exited with status 0
   08/10/18 13:38:36 Warning: Starter pid 6488 is not associated with a claim. A slot may fail to transition to Idle.

followed by lots of StartLog messages like the following 

   08/10/18 13:38:22 slot3: Got activate claim while starter is still alive.
   08/10/18 13:38:22 slot3: Telling shadow to try again later.
   08/10/18 13:38:23 slot3: Got activate claim while starter is still alive.
   08/10/18 13:38:23 slot3: Telling shadow to try again later.
   ...

Immediate Workaround

Until this bug is fixed, a suggested configuration based work around is to simply disable the shared_port daemon on Windows. So first stop the HTCondor service on Windows (net stop condor), then append USE_SHARED_PORT=False to the condor_config[.local] file, the restart the HTCondor service (net start condor). Note this workaround means that HTCondor will no longer use a single well-known TCP port, and thus you may need to adjust firewall rules at your site accordingly.

Reproduce

To reproduce the problem, simply start a personal condor on Windows with shared_port enabled and submit a cluster of short jobs, and time how it takes the cluster of jobs to complete. Now re-run the same test with shared_port disabled, and behold the difference. On my Windows 7 laptop with four cores running HTCondor v8.7.12, the job cluster below took 76 seconds (!!!) to complete with shared_port enabled and just 7 seconds with shared_port disabled : 

   executable = c:\utils\sleep.exe
   arguments = 0
   transfer_executable = false
   log = fast.log
   queue 20

Suggested Source Code Patch

Suggest that we first get signals working again reliably on Windows, perhaps by always having DaemonCore enable the UDP command port (even if shared_port is enabled) and then having the parent UDP signal directly to the child without going through shared port.

Longer term, we should also consider having the condor_starter simply exit when it is done instead of waiting around for the startd to tell it to exit. This would have performance benefits on Linux as well.
remarks: This is very likely to be a manifestation of the bug that was fixed in #6960
